comments:
Nursing 321 examines limitations in psychosocial functioning of individuals and families that are due to psychiatric disorders. Content focuses on the bio-behavioral basis of psychiatric disorders, as well as the psychosocial, developmental, and physiological needs of individuals and their families. Care of individuals having acute episodes and chronic problems are also discussed.

Students generally felt that the course was “run well.” Many felt that some lectures were “great” and “phenomenal,” while others were just “ok.” Students reported that they “really enjoyed the course” and that they “enjoyed learning about psych.” Some, however, expressed frustration at the format of the course and felt that certain lectures were much better than others. 

Most students appreciated several of Professor Roman’s lectures, but found there to be discrepancies in the expectations from different clinical instructors. Some commented that PowerPoint presentations were “poorly done in almost every lecture,” which made taking notes in class difficult.

One student commented, “There is an appropriate level of work for the class.” However, others felt that “there seemed to be a large discrepancy between the amount of work and the total clinical hours for each group.” Additionally, some agreed that the course “could [have] incorporate[d] assigned readings more.” One student commented that this course “should be taken after completion of N104/106 and before OB/Peds and Med/Surg/Gero.” Prerequisites include NURS 210, 220, 240, and 270.
